posts.name: Kalimul
posts.cooked:
This is extremely important. Our team, Team 694 Stuypulse, utilized two Light Leverage 4s (LL4s) placed on the front and back sides of our robot to achieve precise pose estimation during alignment to the reef. However, we encountered an issue where, when our cameras failed to detect a tag, our pose estimates became inaccurate due solely to wheel odometry. We employed the Swerve Drive PID to Pose code from the Cross The Road Electronics (CTRE) platform, which manages odometry calculations. After extensive testing, we confirmed the accuracy of critical parameters such as wheel diameter and gear ratio.

A few weeks prior, we tested our odometry by running a PID control loop with cameras disabled, driving the robot at varying distances (5, 10, and 15 ft). The robot autonomously adjusted its speed based on proximity to a setpoint, stopping when within an inch tolerance. We found that odometry performance improved at lower speeds and accelerations, likely due to increased wheel slip at higher velocities.

We compared actual travel distances with intended distances, observing consistent underestimation, especially at higher speeds and accelerations. To address this, we examined potential factors affecting odometry and sought improvements. Additional details, including our robot code and PID implementation, are available on GitHub.

posts.name: Isaac
posts.cooked: What swerve module are you using in what gear ratio, and what is the frame size?

posts.name: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)
posts.cooked: If it was always low, I’d really consider decreasing your wheel diameter. You said you checked wheel diameter, but what is your process for that? Do you measure it directly or do you run other tests to determine it? For example, we will run a fixed distance at the higher end of speed/accel without slip and compare and adjust wheel diameter from that. At higher accels avoiding wheel slip seems hard.
posts.display_username: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked: The wheel radius has been increased by one. Our old-school 4" SDS aluminum billet wheels with neoprene tread running on Neyland II carpet operate best with a 1.90" radius for new tread and 1.89" for fairly worn tread. Using a nominal 2" radius introduces a 5% odometry error. Adjusting this setting won’t resolve wheel slip issues during high acceleration, though it may address much of the observed inaccuracy.

posts.name: Kalimul
posts.cooked: We used a caliper to measure the wheel diameter though I now realize the value might have been slightly less than what's coded. I'll confirm this at our next meeting and update accordingly.

reply_to_user.name: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked: Calibrate your wheel radius by performing measured driving on carpet or utilizing the spin-in-place characterization routine found in the provided link. The interaction between your tread and the carpet is crucial and may not be accurately predicted by calipers. Additionally, factors such as the force applied to the flexible tread and the positioning of the jaw edges relative to the tread texture must be considered when using calipers for calibration.

posts.name: Mete Karadeniz
posts.cooked: I haven't looked your code, but we had the same issue that you faced. In our code, when we customize the inverse kinematics, it was solved, and odometry calculates accurately.
